answers.answer: It's a good idea to speak to your doctor.  Print out the material you are reading, and take it in, and say this is exactly what happens to you.  A friend of mine correctly diagnosed that he had diabetes from reading medical websites, and another was able to figure out that his son had appendicitis, so even though people who have the tendency to be hypochondriacs probably have no business reading the Internet and brooding on every symptom, it is also true that people can sometimes accurately identify what they have by looking online.  The next step is to see a doctor, though, not to ask on a website.  Good luck!

I don't think you're describing the disorder you're googling.  That's a response by sufferers of autism.  You don't describe yourself in a way that would suggest autism.  I have no idea what is going on, but I can tell you this:  googling symptoms is a bad idea.  Google is very useful when you have a diagnosis, but when you google just symptoms, well, there's always a disease that includes those symptoms.  Usually many diseases.  So as the above counsels, if you believe you have a medical problem, first step is to see a doctor.  Now, if you get a prescription, or a diagnosis and a treatment, that's a good time to google authoritative sites, so you can double check and make sure you haven't seen a quack -- the world is rife with them.  But without a diagnosis, you're just googling air.

question: I'm 16, going on 17, and I believe to have something called a "stereotypy disorder". I haven't been diagnosed, but my symptoms match up perfectly with the symptoms that the disorder describes. When I'm overly excited, my hands, face, feet, and arms will begin to shake involuntarily and uncontrollably for about a few seconds, until I notice I'm doing it and can stop it. Other than that, I'm completely normal, and have no issues whatsoever. So am I right in assuming that I have a stereotypy disorder?
title: Is what I'm experiencing a stereotypy disorder?
